VL: Vulgar Lulani
This section details particular categories of vocabulary items.
Fricatives do not have complete closure of the vocal tract, but are formed with enough constriction to bring turbulence to the airstream.
Consonants are differentiated by manner and place of articulation, and by word-internal gemination. Plosives also have contrasting voice.

The voiced plosives are fully voiced word-internally and partially voiced word-initially. Voiced geminate plosives are given breathy voice. Voiceless plosives are lightly aspirated, which is suppressed in voiceless geminate plosives.
stop voiced nasal lateral central fricative
Plosives are differentiated by voicing, although voiced consonants tend to be rarer than their voiceless counterparts.

The approximants are mainly differentiated by laterality. This language lacks phonemic glides. Like nasals, approximants are prototypically voiced, and geminates are held for 1 ½ times as long as non-geminates.

The voiced plosives are fully voiced word-internally and partially voiced word-initially. Voiced geminate plosives are given breathy voice. Voiceless plosives are lightly aspirated, which is suppressed in voiceless geminate plosives.

There are nasal consonants at each of the places of articulation of the plosives. However, the palatal nasal is only found when geminating the alveolar nasal. Nasals are prototypically voiced. Geminate nasals are held for 1 ½ times as long as non-geminates.

High Lulani phonology has 18 consonant sounds and 3 vowels. Plosives are the only class that have a voicing distinction; fricatives are prototypically voiceless, and resonants are prototypically voiced. Vowels are defined in terms of openness and frontness; there are no oral, length or tone distinctions. All High Lulani words are formed from alternating consonant-vowel pairs. Any word-internal consonant can be geminated.

The fricative /h/ is a voiceless sound. When geminate, it is pronounced as a palatal fricative.

High Lulani phonology has 18 consonant sounds and 3 vowels. Plosives are the only class that have a voicing distinction; fricatives are prototypically voiceless, and resonants are prototypically voiced. Vowels are defined in terms of openness and frontness; there are no oral, length or tone distinctions. All High Lulani words are formed from alternating consonant-vowel pairs. Any word-internal consonant can be geminated.

Phonemically, all syllables are CV, that is, one consonant followed by one vowel. Word-internal consonants can be geminated. The only consonant clusters are geminate consonants, and there are no vowel clusters or long vowels.
If there are no geminates, then the final vowel, and every second vowel going backwards are their own syllables.
The back close vowel is rounded. It can be realised as /u/ or /ʉ/.
The front close vowel is unrounded. It is realised as /i/ or /ɨ/.
The open vowel is unrounded. It can be realised as /a/ or /ə/.

The suffix illu promotes the object. This suffix replaces the final vowel of the verb. The old subject is then marked with the ablative case. A sentence with this marker is intransitive. The demoted item is not compulsory, but if it is put in, it is the first ablative-marked noun in the new sentence.
The glottal stop is one of the most common sounds. Non-geminate glottal stops are often suppressed between unstressed vowels. The second of a geminate glottal stop becomes a palatal approximant /j/.

High Lulani phonology has 18 consonant sounds and 3 vowels. Plosives are the only class that have a voicing distinction; fricatives are prototypically voiceless, and resonants are prototypically voiced. Vowels are defined in terms of openness and frontness; there are no oral, length or tone distinctions. All High Lulani words are formed from alternating consonant-vowel pairs. Any word-internal consonant can be geminated.

The three basic arguments for any verb (intransitive subjects, transitive subjects and transitive objects) are marked in High Lulani. Because intransitive subjects cannot co-occur with transitive arguments, it is possible to mark either of the transitive arguments in the same way as the intransitive without confusion. In the ergative alignment, it is the transitive object that is marked the same as the intransitive subject. In accusative alignment, it is instead the transitive subject that shares marking with intransitive subjects. In either alignment, the intransitive case is the one treated like the intransitive subject, and the transitive case is the other.

When a single Tinellbian function morpheme fulfills two or more grammatical roles, a semi-colon ( ; ) is used to separate them.
When two or more English content morphemes correspond to a single Tinellbian morpheme, an underscore ( _ ) is used to separate them.

When a number is written out in digits, each set of four digits from the fractional point makes up a group. The group furthest from the fractional point may not have this full quota of digits. An index marker notes the identity of a particular group.

When writing out a number, each digit is worth fifteen times as much as the following digit. A period (fractional point: . ) is used to separate the integer part of the number from the mantissa. A comma (,) is used in the integer part to separate the digits into groupings of four, beginning from the fractional point.

High Lulani is an analytic agglutinative language, as morphemes tend to keep their own shape, even when forming words.
Alienable possession is used in a hierarchy when the possessor is of higher rank than the possessed, and inalienable possession when the relationship is the other way around.
Distal pronouns are used when the referent is far away.
Possession is alienable when the possessed item can be transferred from one owner to another. Alienable possessions include objects bought or received by a person.

The ‘object’ indefinite pronouns can modify a noun when used as a suffix. When cu’i nothing is used as a suffix, it loses its last syllable. When ’umi something is used as a suffix, it loses its first syllable.
The alveolar nasal /n/ is apical. When geminated, this sound is palatal and laminal.
The consonant /ɹ/ is central and laminal. When geminated, this sound becomes a trill.
The consonant /l/ is lateral and apical. When geminated, this sound is laminal and palatal.
The fricative /h/ is a voiceless sound. When geminate, it is pronounced as a palatal fricative.

There are nasal consonants at each of the places of articulation of the plosives. However, the palatal nasal is only found when geminating the alveolar nasal. Nasals are prototypically voiced. Geminate nasals are held for 1 ½ times as long as non-geminates.

The most basic use for an adposition is prefixed to a noun to signify where the action is taking place with relation to a reference.
The dynamic aspect is used for changes of state, and actions that occupy one moment in time. The exception is verbs of perception, where the action may be taking place over a period of time.

The stative aspect is used for temporary states and attributes, or for continual actions taking place over a period of time. The exception again is verbs of perception, where the stative aspect denotes potentiality, that is, the ability to perceive the stimulus.

Adpositions can be used by themselves to show the position of the action relative to the speaker, or the direction in which the action proceeds. Unlike other adverbs, these are placed after the auxiliary.

Auxiliaries are a type of helper verb, however, they are sufficiently different from main verbs for them to be treated separately in this grammar. They are used to mark tense (the time at which an action takes place) and aspect (the nature of the passage of time during the action). The auxiliary can be dropped from a sentence if it is obvious from context, or is the same as that of the sentence immediately prior. They are a closed class.

The negative aspect is used for actions, attributes and perceptions which do not occur. These act as the negation of any other aspectual marker. That is, while positive sentences can be classified by aspect, negative sentences all use the same auxiliaries.
The three tenses are past, present and future. In conversation, the tenses tend to mark the time at which the action began or occurred.
Conjunctions are a closed class of words which are used to join phrases or clauses together.
Inalienable possession refers to items which are unable to be transferred from one individual to another. Inalienable possessions include relatives, parts of the body and objects created by a person.

Interrogative and imperative sentences (questions and orders) are denoted by tone. This tone is either a rising tone (&#x1ce) or a falling tone (â), placed on the syllable of the appropriate word which has the greatest stress.

The first noun in a clause is the subject, which is prototypically the agent in transitive sentences and the patient in intransitive sentences. However, suffixes can be added to the verb to promote other nouns in the clause, other than the genitive.
There are three such verbal suffixes, which can be stacked, however, once something has been shifted from the subject position, it can’t be promoted again.
An adverbial clause is one which acts as an adverb.
Content questions are ones in which the expected answer is more than just “yes” or “no”. These questions have a rising tone on the main question word itself.
Polar questions are one in which the answer is “yes” or “no”. They are spoken with a rising tone on the last word. The auxiliaries are used to answer.

The suffix illu promotes the object. This suffix replaces the final vowel of the verb. The old subject is then marked with the ablative case. A sentence with this marker is intransitive. The demoted item is not compulsory, but if it is put in, it is the first ablative-marked noun in the new sentence.

The suffix pakka abp promotes an ablative. The old subject is demoted to object, and the old object is demoted to dative. A sentence with this marker is transitive. The first dative-marked noun in the new sentence is the demoted item.
The suffix xa promotes a dative. The old subject is demoted to object, and the old object (if any) is demoted to dative. A sentence with this marker is transitive.
To promote a adpositional phrase to subject, prefix the verb with the adposition. The old subject is demoted to object. The old object, if any, is demoted to dative.

Sometimes the verb requires an oblique rather than a traditional object. In these cases, the subject is usually in intransitive case, although it is not incorrect to use transitive case with dynamic and iterative auxiliaries.
The ablative case is used to mark the proximate cause or the instigator of an action. With verbs of transfer or motion, it is also used to mark the source of a movement. The clitic is kalu.

The dative case was originally only used to mark the receiver with verbs of giving and transfer. The meaning has since broadened to show indirectness on the part of the patient for a number of verbs, including verbs of perception and emotion. The clitic is ku-.

The three basic arguments for any verb (intransitive subjects, transitive subjects and transitive objects) are marked in High Lulani. Because intransitive subjects cannot co-occur with transitive arguments, it is possible to mark either of the transitive arguments in the same way as the intransitive without confusion. In the ergative alignment, it is the transitive object that is marked the same as the intransitive subject. In accusative alignment, it is instead the transitive subject that shares marking with intransitive subjects. In either alignment, the intransitive case is the one treated like the intransitive subject, and the transitive case is the other.
The two oblique cases are marked on the pronouns. For common and proper nouns, a clitic with the same form as the appropriate third person inanimate pronoun is placed before the noun phrase.
An item possessed by the third-person subject of a matrix clause need not appear with a genitive marker, whether the possession is alienable or inalienable.
“That we’ve always been at war with Eastasia, is what I think.”

A content clause is one that takes the place of a noun. They begin with the complementiser li and are separated from the matrix clause by commas. The auxiliary is not optional, and is given a low tone. Quote marks are used around reported speech, replacing the complementiser.
Polar questions are one in which the answer is “yes” or “no”. They are spoken with a rising tone on the last word. The auxiliaries are used to answer.

Relative clauses specify the noun by describing it. They are placed before the modified noun, beginning with the relativiser xiku. The auxiliary is not optional, and is given a rising tone. Only subjects can be relativised. Other cases must be promoted to subject.

Second person imperatives are directed to the listener. In these, the subject is dropped, a future auxiliary in the appropriate aspect is suffixed to the verb, and this verb complex is moved to the end of the sentence. These are spoken with a falling tone on the auxiliary.

Vowels are defined in terms of openness and frontness; there are no oral, length or tone distinctions. All High Lulani words are formed from alternating consonant-vowel pairs. Any word-internal consonant can be geminated.

Phonemically, all syllables are CV, that is, one consonant followed by one vowel. Word-internal consonants can be geminated. The only consonant clusters are geminate consonants, and there are no vowel clusters or long vowels.
Falling tone can also be used to bring focus to a particular word.
In a stem word, primary stress falls on the last closed syllable, and secondary stress on the penultimate closed syllable.

Interrogative and imperative sentences (questions and orders) are denoted by tone. This tone is either a rising tone (&#x1ce) or a falling tone (â), placed on the syllable of the appropriate word which has the greatest stress.
Content questions are ones in which the expected answer is more than just “yes” or “no”. These questions have a rising tone on the main question word itself.
Polar questions are one in which the answer is “yes” or “no”. They are spoken with a rising tone on the last word. The auxiliaries are used to answer.
The word ma where is often used as a prefix for adpositions used as clausal conjunctions.

I have been interested in language and linguistics since at least the age of 10. I remember making up words when I was quite young. In fact, the High Lulani word mica hello dates from that time.

A bonded female is called a julliga married woman, and the male equivalent is a xalli married man. These terms are not used with possessives. On the other hand, the words kitisu wife and silu husband are used with possessives.

The words sabba father and piha mother usually refer to biological parents, but can be applied to the main guardians if the biological parents are not around. These are used both with and without possessives.
There is a closed class of true adjectives, words used to give qualities of a noun.

A subclass of adverb are the modals, words used to denote properties of sentences, such as their reality, probability or the speaker’s emotions towards the topic. These may only be used independently.
Conjunctions are a closed class of words which are used to join phrases or clauses together.
These conjunctions are used to join clauses or sentences. They are used as independent words.
These conjunctions are used to join words or phrases. They are enclitics.
High Lulani is an analytic agglutinative language, as morphemes tend to keep their own shape, even when forming words.

The first part of a compound noun must be a noun, and the subsequent parts specify the meaning of that noun. These parts can be nouns or verbs. The whole noun is usually written without spaces. The syllabification and stress of nonce words are determined on a stem-by-stem basis. However, a compound in common use will start being treated whole.

There are very few words with specific gender, mostly those dealing with family, as well as lulani queen and kimilli king. In these cases, the feminine form is the default, for people of undefined, unknown or non-binary gender.
There are very few particles. These are simply words that do not fit neatly into any other category.
A central dot  is placed between words, and sentences begin and end with a  symbol.

High Lulani phonology has 18 consonant sounds and 3 vowels. Plosives are the only class that have a voicing distinction; fricatives are prototypically voiceless, and resonants are prototypically voiced. Any word-internal consonant can be geminated.

The Tinellbian languages are a range of constructed languages, as befits the constructed universe of Tinellb. In that world, the ancestor language was created by Queen Loren of the Ptokonoi, and then evolved naturally as different groups of people moved through space, time and reality.

Despite their shared language, as more time went by, fractures again showed between nations. Another world war ensued. A great weapon was created, one that tore apart space-time, flinging its victims far out into the universe.

Generations passed. The people rebuilt their shattered world. The newest ruler, Queen Loren, decided to create an international language to promote peace amongst her subjects. She named this language Lulani after herself.
One such group were the Fezhlê. They found themselves on a world already inhabited by the Zhaladi. The Fezhlê tongue evolved independently from Lulani, and was influenced by Zhaladi dialects.

There had been many conflicts, small and large, throughout their history. One particularly bloody war had had much of the population brought into it: a World War. The survivors of this war were ruled by a single monarch.

Within the universe named Tinellb, there is a planet named Ptoko. There arose on this world a race of humanoids, the Ptokan. Over millions of years, their race evolved and became the dominant force on their planet.

When writing out a number, each digit is worth fifteen times as much as the following digit. A period (fractional point: . ) is used to separate the integer part of the number from the mantissa. A comma (,) is used in the integer part to separate the digits into groupings of four, beginning from the fractional point.

When I decided to write a novel, a constructed language (conlang) was an obvious prospect for inclusion in the background information. I had the beginnings of what was to be the Ptokan language, and the language of the Fezhlê. The latter  was once designed as a daughter language of Ptokan, but it had some features, mostly phonological, that seemed to come from an earlier language. Thus was Lulani born. Originally intended to be a phonology sketch, Lulani has expanded greatly into a language in its own right. So much so, in fact, that Ptokan and Fezhlê have been forced to change somewhat to adapt.

A comma (,) is used in the integer part to separate the digits into groupings of four, beginning from the fractional point.

A content mropheme is written in either roman or italic type.
A function morpheme is written in small-caps.
High Lulani numbers are written with the positive digits (1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6 and 7), their negative counterparts (1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6 and 7) and a zero (0).

When a number is written out in digits, each set of four digits from the fractional point makes up a group. The group furthest from the fractional point may not have this full quota of digits. An index marker notes the identity of a particular group.

It is written in horizontal rows, right-to-left, and top-to-bottom.

The internal history of the Guozu and their languages is written as if it were a chronicle of actual events. The external history is the more prosaic record: a description of the genesis and evolution of my ideas.

Relative clauses specify the noun by describing it. They are placed before the modified noun, beginning with the relativiser xiku. The auxiliary is not optional, and is given a rising tone. Only subjects can be relativised. Other cases must be promoted to subject.
Xiku kalukimilli lu’illu pi lulani.
Xiku lu’i kimilli pi Sa’imi.
Xiku lu’i kimilli pi lulani.
Xiku lu’i kimilli pi mihu.

Baju blue covers both light and dark blue, the darkest violets, and all but the lightest shades of green. Sa yellow covers the lightest shades of orange and green, as well as standard yellow. Miku red refers to all of red and pink, light purples and most of the orange spectrum, however, dark orange is subsumed under millu brown.
